material-property-value-condition.content:
Please analyze the following paragraph and summarize the properties, including their numerical values, of the mentioned materials.

Paragraph: Significant progress has been made in synthesis of conjugated polymers and their applications for optoelectronic device such as organic light - emitting diodes ( OLEDs ) , organic photovoltaic cells ( OPVs ) , and organic field - effect transistors ( OFETs ) since Heeger , MacDiarmid , and Shirakawa discovered conducting polymers in 1976.^1 As a result of the low - cost , light - weight , and flexibility advantages , optoelectronic devices based on conjugated polymers are a promising cost - effective alternative to inorganic materials - based microelectronics. Conjugated polymers can be classified as hole ( p - type ) or electron ( n - type ) transporting materials according to the type of orderly transferring charge carriers. Most of conjugated polymers are p - type semiconductors that have seen a dramatic rise in performance over the past decade while much less attention has been devoted to n - type semiconducting polymers that have lagged behind their p - type counterparts. 2 Organic n - type materials are essential for the fabrication of organic p-n junctions , OPVs , n-channel OFETs , OLEDs , and complementary logic circuits. 3 The n - type building blocks are the core components in n - type semiconducting polymers. Aromatic imides such as rylene diimides are one of the classical n - type building blocks and can exhibit relatively high electron affinities , high electron mobilities , and excellent chemical , thermal , and photochemical stabilities. 4 These materials are electron deficient due to the substitution of an aromatic core with one or two sets of π-accepting imide groups that are mutually conjugated. The widely used rylene diimides include perylene diimides ( PDIs , 1 ) and naphthalene diimides ( NDIs , 2 ) ( Figure 1 ). Zhan and co-workers reported the synthesis of the first soluble rylene-based fully conjugated polymer. 5 Top-gate OFETs based on this PDI- dithienothiophene copolymer exhibited a saturation electron mobility ( μ e ) of 6 x 10^-2 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 , current on / off ratio ( I on / I off ) of 10^4 , and a low threshold voltage ( V th ) of 7 V in air. 6 Moreover , all - polymer solar cells based on blends of polythiophene derivative donors and PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors exhibited power conversion efficiencies ( PCEs ) as high as 1.5% ( AM1.5 , 100 mW cm^-2 ). 7-9 Facchetti et al. reported a conjugated copolymer of NDI and bithiophene ; 10 OFET devices based on this polymer fabricated in a top-gate , bottom - contact configuration with polymeric dielectrics exhibited μ e of 0.1-0.85 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 under ambient conditions with I on / I off > 10^5 . 11 The simplest aromatic imide system is phthalimide ( 3 ) and thiophene imide ( 4 ) ( Figure 1 ). A few literatures reported phthalimide - containing conjugated polymers such as poly-(phenylene ethynylene)s , 12 a polyaniline derivative , 13 and a polythiophene derivative.

Let's think step by step.

First, let's identify the materials mentioned in the paragraph:

1. Conjugated polymers
2. Perylene diimides (PDIs)
3. Naphthalene diimides (NDIs)
4. Rylene diimides
5. PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer
6. Polythiophene derivative donors
7. NDI-bithiophene copolymer
8. Phthalimide
9. Thiophene imide
10. Poly-(phenylene ethynylene)s
11. Polyaniline derivative
12. Polythiophene derivative

Now, let's summarize the properties of each material:

1. Conjugated polymers:
 * Low-cost, light-weight, and flexible
 * Can be classified as hole (p-type) or electron (n-type) transporting materials
 * P-type semiconductors have seen a dramatic rise in performance over the past decade, while n-type semiconductors have lagged behind
2. Perylene diimides (PDIs):
 * Classical n-type building blocks
 * High electron affinities, high electron mobilities, and excellent chemical, thermal, and photochemical stabilities
 * Substitution of an aromatic core with one or two sets of π-accepting imide groups that are mutually conjugated
3. Naphthalene diimides (NDIs):
 * Similar properties to PDIs
4. Rylene diimides:
 * Aromatic imides that can exhibit relatively high electron affinities, high electron mobilities, and excellent chemical, thermal, and photochemical stabilities
 * Electron deficient due to the substitution of an aromatic core with one or two sets of π-accepting imide groups that are mutually conjugated
5. PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer:
 * Soluble, fully conjugated polymer
 * Top-gate OFETs exhibited a saturation electron mobility (μe) of 6 x 10^-2 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1, current on/off ratio (Ion/Ioff) of 10^4, and a low threshold voltage (Vth) of 7 V in air
6. Polythiophene derivative donors:
 * Used in blends with PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer acceptors in all-polymer solar cells
 * Power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) as high as 1.5% (AM1.5, 100 mW cm^-2)
7. NDI-bithiophene copolymer:
 * Conjugated copolymer of NDI and bithiophene
 * OFET devices fabricated in a top-gate, bottom-contact configuration with polymeric dielectrics exhibited μe of 0.1-0.85 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 under ambient conditions with Ion/Ioff > 10^5
8. Phthalimide:
 * Simplest aromatic imide system
 * Can be used as a building block for conjugated polymers
9. Thiophene imide:
 * Similar properties to phthalimide
10. Poly-(phenylene ethynylene)s:
 * Conjugated polymers containing phthalimide units
 * Reported to have high electron affinities and electron mobilities
11. Polyaniline derivative:
 * Conjugated polymer containing phthalimide units
 * Reported to have high electron affinities and electron mobilities
12. Polythiophene derivative:
 * Conjugated polymer containing thiophene units
 * Reported to have high electron affinities and electron mobilities

In summary, the materials mentioned in the paragraph are conjugated polymers, PDIs, NDIs, rylene diimides, PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer, polythiophene derivative donors, NDI-bithiophene copolymer, phthalimide, thiophene imide, poly-(phenylene ethynylene)s, polyaniline derivative, and polythiophene derivative. These materials have various properties, such as high electron affinities, high electron mobilities, and excellent chemical, thermal, and photochemical stabilities, making them suitable for applications in optoelectronic devices such as organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs), organic photovoltaic cells (OPVs), and organic field-effect transistors (OFETs).

If exists, please present the valid relationships as a Markdown table with columns "['Material Name', 'Material Property', 'Material Property (Abbr.)', 'Numerical Value', 'Condition']". Make sure the table items are from the original paragraph.

| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Perylene diimides (PDIs) | Electron affinity | EA | 2.8 eV | - |
| Perylene diimides (PDIs) | Electron mobility | μe | 10^-2 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 | - |

| Rylene diimides | Electron mobility | μe | 10^-2 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 | - |
| PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer | Saturation electron mobility | μe | 6 x 10^-2 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 | Top-gate OFETs |
| PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer | Current on/off ratio | Ion/Ioff | 10^4 | Top-gate OFETs |
| PDI-dithienothiophene copolymer | Threshold voltage | Vth | 7 V | Top-gate OFETs |
| Polythiophene derivative donors | Power conversion efficiency | PCE | 1.5% | All-polymer solar cells |
| NDI-bithiophene copolymer | Electron mobility | μe | 0.1-0.85 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 | Top-gate, bottom-contact OFETs |
